title: 112_s2041
content: The approval of the Keystone XL pipeline project was granted. TransCanada Keystone Pipeline, L.P. is authorized to construct, connect, operate, and maintain pipeline facilities for the import of crude oil and other hydrocarbons at the United States-Canada Border in Montana, in accordance with the application filed in 2008. No permit is required under Executive Order 13337 or any similar Executive Order. TransCanada Keystone Pipeline, L.P. is authorized to construct, connect, operate, and maintain pipeline facilities at the United States-Canada Border in Montana without the need for an additional environmental impact statement. The final environmental impact statement issued by the Department of State in 2011 satisfies all requirements of the National Environmental Policy Act for the Keystone XL Pipeline project in the United States. TransCanada Keystone Pipeline, L.P. is authorized to construct, connect, operate, and maintain cross-border facilities in the United States as described in the application filed with the Department of State on September 19, 2008. Any permits issued before the enactment of this Act for these facilities shall remain in effect. TransCanada Keystone Pipeline, L.P. must comply with specified conditions during the construction, connection, operation, and maintenance of these facilities. TransCanada Keystone Pipeline, L.P. is required to comply with all applicable laws, regulations, and permits from Canadian and US authorities for the construction, operation, and maintenance of facilities. They must also take measures to prevent environmental impact and disruption of historic properties. The construction, connection, operation, and maintenance of the facilities must be similar to the application filed with the Department of State and the final environmental impact statement. It should also adhere to the construction, mitigation, and reclamation measures agreed upon in the project plan. The special conditions, measures, and stipulations outlined in appendices U, H, and S of the final environmental impact statement must be adhered to by the owners and operators of the project, as agreed upon with the Administrator of the Pipeline and Hazardous Materials Safety Administration. In Nebraska, any route and construction measures identified by the state and submitted to the Secretary of State are sufficient for the project. Construction in Nebraska cannot begin until the Secretary of State receives the approved route from the state. In Nebraska, upon receipt of the approved route by the Secretary of State, it will supersede the previously specified route. The state can request assistance from the Secretary of State or Federal official within 30 days, and any actions to implement this section must comply with Nebraska law. The approval of cross-border facilities and related facilities in the United States does not constitute a major Federal action under the National Environmental Policy Act. State laws regarding pipeline siting and private property access remain unchanged. Federal judicial review applies to approved facilities. The approval of cross-border facilities in the United States is not considered a major Federal action under the National Environmental Policy Act. State laws on pipeline siting and private property access remain unchanged. Any actions taken to construct the project are subject to judicial review on direct appeal to the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.
